meaning: Ходить вокруг да около, не говорить прямо
example: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what you really think.
Let's get straight to the point - we need to cut costs.
You need to read between the lines to understand what he's really saying.

meaning: Заговаривать до смерти, очень много говорить
example: My uncle talked my ear off about his fishing trip for two hours.
I had to hold my tongue during the meeting to avoid an argument.
Who spilled the beans about the surprise party?

idiom: Let the cat out of the bag
example: I accidentally let the cat out of the bag about their engagement.
He told a joke to break the ice at the awkward dinner.
I don't have much time, so let's cut to the chase.
Speak of the devil - we were just talking about you!

idiom: Give someone a piece of your mind
example: I'm going to give him a piece of my mind about his behavior.
I had to bite my tongue when she made that rude comment.
Her silence spoke volumes about her true feelings.
It's time to talk turkey about our business partnership.
We spent the afternoon shooting the breeze on the porch.
I heard it through the grapevine that they're getting divorced.

idiom: Get the wrong end of the stick
example: You've got the wrong end of the stick - I never said that.

meaning: Приписывать кому-то слова, которых он не говорил
example: Don't put words in my mouth - that's not what I said.
I hate it when people talk behind my back.
We speak the same language when it comes to business ethics.
Please keep me in the loop about any changes to the project.
We must have gotten our wires crossed about the meeting time.

meaning: Говорить о разном, не понимать друг друга
example: We were talking at cross purposes the whole time.
After years of silence, she finally broke her silence about the incident.
He gave an amazing speech completely off the cuff.
I won't mince words - your work has been terrible lately.

meaning: Говорить о работе в нерабочее время
example: Let's not talk shop during dinner - we're here to relax.
I need to have a word with you about your punctuality.
She talks so much, I can't get a word in edgewise.
I appreciate that you always speak your mind honestly.

meaning: Ходить вокруг да около в разговоре
example: Stop talking in circles and give me a straight answer.
How should I break it to her gently that she didn't get the job?
The project is very hush-hush - don't tell anyone.

To put it bluntly, your proposal is not good enough.
He's talking through his hat - he knows nothing about the subject.

idiom: Have the gift of the gab
example: Salespeople need to have the gift of the gab.
I spoke too soon - the problem turned out to be more serious.
This information is confidential, so keep it under your hat.
She talked me into going to the party even though I was tired.

Everyone should have a chance to speak their piece.
I can't seem to get through to him - he just won't listen.

He talks big, but he rarely delivers on his promises.
I apologize if I spoke out of turn during the meeting.
I need to get this off my chest - I made a mistake.

meaning: Говорить правильно, но не обязательно действовать
example: He talks the talk, but can he walk the walk?
Stop speaking in riddles and tell me what you mean.

idiom: Talk until you're blue in the face
example: You can talk until you're blue in the face, but I won't change my mind.

idiom: Get straight from the horse's mouth
example: I got the news straight from the horse's mouth - the CEO told me himself.

The awkward silence was finally broken by the phone ringing.

idiom: Talk out of both sides of your mouth
example: Politicians often talk out of both sides of their mouths.

idiom: Speak now or forever hold your peace
example: If anyone has any objections, speak now or forever hold your peace.
